intro.p: Speaking of web-accessibility, the visually impaired have the most painpoints. According to the EBU more than 4% of the european population is blind or partially sighted. They use screen reader. A screen reader is a tool that reads content aloud. There are different types of screen readers, the most popular Screen Readers are JAWS and Zoom Text:

img.alt: Chart of primary screen reader usage showing decreases in JAWS, NVDA, VoiceOver, SA and significant increases in ZoomText and Window-Eyes.
img.caption: Chart based on Data from webaim.org a textual description can be found there.

ul: All concepts introduced on this page were tested with VoiceOver and JAWS in June 2016.
In all outputs under the examples, the headings where replaced by strong tags in order to not confuse screen reader users browsing this page.

paragraphs.li: Screen reader can read text, and interpret special attributes written in HTML, most modern screen reader can also list common items as all headers, links, forms and tables.
The usual painpoints are a bad page strukture, images, svg, graphs, videos, forms, tables, repetitive elements, visual features, popups.
Screen readers have no problems using javascript.
Almost all screen reader obey display:none and visibility:hidden by ignoring the element.
To have elements visually hidden but still accessible for screen readers the W3C suggests this css method:
Of course you can also do the contrary. Hide text for screen readers but show it visually by using aria-hidden="true". The support for aria-hidden is brilliant.
This is how a screenreader would typically interpret the different hiding methods:

example.pre: I love bees cats and you

paragraphs.li: The typical behaviour of screen reader is to read the page from top to bottom. So it is critical that all your element positioning follows the HTML flow. As all modern screen reader use and understand CSS and JavaScript it is important not to mess with that logical flow.
The document outline should be respected. Read more on this in the Headings section. A tool to check your document outline is the html5 outliner.
Use the header tag with role="banner" for the heading of your website (often containing the logo and a searchbar). I.e. like this:

example.audio: Banner, 2 items. -- Google image. -- Search, 2 items. -- search input. -- search button.

paragraphs.li: Any navigation should be contained in a nav tag with role="navigation". This way some screen reader will be able to list all the navigation elements on your page. Learn more on navigations in the Navigation section.

The main content should be in a main tag with role="main". A page should always have main section. Some screen reader allow users to jump directly into the main section of a page and thus skipping the navigation or headings.
The global footer should be in a footer tag with the role="contentinfo" to differentiate it from other footers on the page.
Any supplementary element (that do not fit in the main tag) belong in an aside tag with role="complementary".
The searchbar (with its input, label, button, etc.) should be in a container (can be a form element) with role="search". Some screen reader allow users to jump directly to the search bar.

To group content of a page you can divide it in sections with the section tag and the generic role="region". However, don’t overuse it as it adds text for the screen reader to read. On this page the different sections were groupes using this method, but not their subsections. Like this:

example.pre:
Structure

[...]

Subtitle of Structure

[...]
example.audio: Region 'Structure', 4 items. -- Heading Level 2, Structure. -- content. -- Heading Level 3, Subtitle of Structure. -- content.

paragraphs.li: When structuring your element, the best practice is to use the aria-labelledby attribute and give it the id of the elements heading since all modern screen readers can list headings but not sections. If there is no descriptive heading, at least the aria-label attribute should be used. Let’s demonstrate the different behaviours:

example.pre:
About Sharks

[...]
OR
[...]
OR
[...]
example.audio: Region 'About Sharks' 2 items. -- Heading Level 2, About Sharks. -- content. | OR. -- Region 'Shark Fakts' 1 item. -- content. | OR. -- Region 1 item. -- content.

paragraphs.li: Use the right tags for the job:

Beside giving a visual clue, screen reader can list all headings. A screen reader user will typically scan a pages headings and then jump imediately to that section. Therefor the logical flow of headings is more than important. Nest headings accordingly: h1 > h2 > h3 > ... without skipping a level.
therefore it is also important to give all your page sections a specific heading with aria-labelledby as seen before under Structure.
Wen browsing over a heading, its level is read aloud:
The role="heading" is not necessary if you use h tags. It might be used to declare another element than an h tag as a heading with role="heading" aria-level="7". I.e. to get deeper than h6
Write the key information at the beginning.
paragraphs.pre:
• Great White Shark Facts
  • Hammerhead Shark Facts
  • Facts about great white sharks
  • Facts about Hammerhead sharks

paragraphs.li: Usually the first heading is the page name or the overall heading, the second headings indicate the different sections
Also have a look at the guidelines regarding headings for people with cognitive disabilities.
Use list of links to help screen readers announce the number of links a menu has. Generally use unordered lists ul but when the order matters as in table of contents use ordered lists ol.

Indicate the current page by adding 'Current Page:' in front of the respective element in the menu. Additionally, to make sure that the current page is obvious, the current page should not be linked. See the example below.

Wrap the menu in a nav tag with role="navigation" and a heading to label the menu. That heading can be visually hidden. This is an accessible menu that enables users to find it when listing all the headings or menus:

example.pre:
Main Menu

  • Current: Home
  • About
  • Contact
example.audio: Navigation 'Main Menu', 2 items. -- Heading Level 2, Main Menu. -- Current. -- Home. -- Link, about. -- Link, contact.

paragraphs.li: Drop downs should be only visually hidden to be accessible for screen reader. Ideally the visuallyhidden class would then be toggled via javascript. See hiding elements and the example below for further information.
Usually a drop down is another odered or unordered list inside the list item of the first ordered or unordered list:
paragraphs.pre:
Some Example Navigation

  • Section1
  • Section2
    • Section2-1
    • Section2-2
  • Section3

paragraphs.li: Use a nav tag with role="navigation" and aria-label="you are here". Also add a visually hidden indice “current” to the last item.

example.pre: Home > About Sharks > Current: Hammerhead Shark Facts.
example.audio: Navigation 'You are here', 6 items. -- Link, Home. -- > -- Link, About Sharks. -- > -- Current. -- Hammerhead Shark Facts.

paragraphs.li: Not every screen reader has advanced mechanism to jump to sections, headings, links, etc. or to skip repetitive codeblocks as Tables, Codeblocks, etc. So, this is probably one of the most important thing for a good screen reader user experience is providing links to jump immediatly to relevant sections and/or to skip repetitive content. On this page skip links were added before each code example to skip it. Moreover a visually hidden skip link was added at the begining of the page granting screen reader users the possibility to jump directly to either the table of contents, the menu or the content. PS: There is also a visually hidden easter egg somewhere, can you spot it?

Skip links are like normal links pointing to anchors (elements with IDs) on your page. You might want to hide them visually but display them on focus to improve the usability of your page for keyboard users as well:

example.pre:
Item

Skip annoying content to next item

Annoying Content

Next item
example.audio: Item. -- Link, Skip annoying content to next item. -- Press link: Skip annoying content to next item -- Next item.

paragraphs.li: It is a good practice to have a table of content linking to each heading within a long text. A table of content is nothing other than a navigation menu.
Any tabular data should be written in Tables as some screen reader have special features to recognise tables.
Add a caption to your table explaining what it is about. Hide it visually if it is obvious for visual users.

To make sure that the screen readers read your tables correctly include scoping. Use scope="col" to identify the columns and scope="row" to identify rows and scope="colgroup" whenever a column spans over more than one item. This is how a complex accessible table could look like:

example.pre:
Edible elements:
Edible Not Edible Maybe Edible
Apple Fruit Computer Corporation Special
example.audio: Edible elements, table 5 columns, 2 rows. -- Edible, column 2. -- Spans 2 columns, Not edible, column 3. -- Maybe edible, colum 5. -- Row 2, Apple. -- Edible, Fruit, column 2. -- Not edible, Computer, column 3 -- Corporation. -- Maybe edible, Special, column 5.

paragraphs.li: Do not use tables for layout purpose, that is not what they are intendet for. It would probably mess up the screen reader.
Keep it simple. If you have complex data, use several Tables to represent it instead of one. [V][A][P][C]
Give table data a different look to table headings. [A][P][C]
Zebra tables (where every second row has a light background) are good practice for long tables so that the user don’t get lost [A][P][C]
You can use your SVGs within an img tag, then the same rules as for images apply.

If you inline your SVG and they are a collection of elements that form an image. Then add role="img" to your container. Then, add a role="presentation" to the svg elements to hide them from the screen reader, as seen in the example below.

If they are not purely decorative elements usually a title with the respective aria-labeledby="titleID" will be sufficient. However, if you have a complex image that you want to fully describe, provide da desc tag and link it in the same aria-labeledby="titleID descID". Here is an example borrowed from the paciellogroup:

example.pre:
<svg xmlns=http://www.w3.org/2000/svg role="img" aria-labelledby="title  desc">
   <title id="title">Circle</title>
   <desc id="desc">Large circle with a fat border</desc>
   <circle role="presentation" cy="60" cx="60" r="35" stroke="black" stroke-width="2" 
   fill="grey" />
</svg>
example.audio: Circle large circle with a fat border, image.

paragraphs.li: You can use text and links within svg.
If your SVG contains content that is interactive, you’ll need to make sure that the interactive elements are targetable. Give the elements a role="link".

writings.screenReader: When you build a website or a webapp, you want it to be successfull. Right?
You want everyone to use it. Right?
Then, why would you leave out eleven percent of the population?
texts: Then, why would you leave out

writings.screenReader: Imagine increasing sales by eleven percent, while doing good. Neat right?
Open up your websites for the physically impaired. Make them accessible!
It is not difficult, nor will it cost a fortune. You have no excuse.
Accessibility is like opening your door to everyone.
